qas.question: When are these texts first able to reach a large amount of people?
Erasmus can be said to have lit the match that sparked a radical change in thinking in his era along with who?
What text still remained without the type of thorough review that others texts had received by the 18th century?
When are these texts first able to reach no amount of people?
What text no longer remains without the type of thorough review that others texts had received by the 12th century?
Where was Renaissance humanism against the law?
What focused on dismissing scholarship and philology?
What 18th century German school has no criticisms?

context: After <b3_0>1517<b3_0/>, when the new invention of printing made these texts widely available, the Dutch humanist <a0_0>Erasmus<a0_0/>, who had studied Greek at the Venetian printing house of Aldus Manutius, began a philological analysis of the Gospels in the spirit of Valla, comparing the Greek originals with their Latin translations with a view to correcting errors and discrepancies in the latter. Erasmus, along with the French humanist Jacques <a1_0>Lefèvre d'Étaples<a1_0/>, began issuing new translations, laying the groundwork for the Protestant Reformation. Henceforth Renaissance humanism, particularly in the <b5_0>German North<b5_0/>, became concerned with religion, while Italian and <b6_0>French humanism<b6_0/> concentrated increasingly on scholarship and philology addressed to a narrow audience of specialists, studiously avoiding topics that might offend despotic rulers or which might be seen as corrosive of faith. After the Reformation, critical examination of <a2_0><b4_0>the Bible<b4_0/><a2_0/> did not resume until the advent of the so-called Higher criticism of the 19th-century German <b7_0>Tübingen school<b7_0/>.
